choices.A: To create a chain of evidence to demonstrate when the servers were patched.
choices.D: To generate log data for unreleased patches.
choices.C: To provide validation that the remediation was active.
choices.B: To harden the servers against new attacks.

questions.question_text: After implementing and running an automated patching tool, a security administrator ran a vulnerability scan that reported no missing patches found. Which of the following BEST describes why this tool was used?

discussion.content: Hang on -- it says why was the 'tool' used -- the tool in this case must be the first tool, which was used to harden. The scan was not a tool. Trying to trick us ...
Correct answer shouLd be B as the question asked why the tool was used . Tool in question here is the automated patch management tool. The scanning is not a tool but a process or an activity
B is correct as it say "Why was the tool used"...
I think B is correct as there was no mention of any existing vuln. It is simply an initiative why the automated patching is set in place. To harden the Servers...
Shouldn't it be C. If you have just patched, then you run the scan to confirm your patch has worked!

comments.content: correction - This is hardening because it is talking specifically of the tool used for automated patching... patching is a form of hardening

discussion.content: C - there is no suggestion of hardening taking place for B

choices.D: Sequentially sent an ICMP echo reply to the Class C network.
choices.B: Performed a half open SYB scan on the network.
choices.C: Sent 255 ping packets to each host on the network.
choices.A: Performed a ping sweep of the Class C network.

discussion.content: For those who believe A and D are exactly the same thing: A is sending an echo-request and D is sending an echo-reply (not quite sure if you can even send and echo-reply without having seen an echo-request first).
This is a SQL injection attack using union. Answer should be letter B - requiring input validation.
It's s SQL injection attempt. An input validation should be performed

https://www.netsparker.com/blog/web-security/sql-injection-vulnerability/#WhatIsAnSQLInjectionVulnerability
Does not matter whether HTTP or HTTPS - SQL injection can work either way.
B. Input validation is a better answer.
I think the answer is correct here, first line of defense should be to secure the communication protocol in use in this case an unsecured HTTP

comments.content:
Dude read the question "prevent this code from performing malicious actions" should be validate the input.

Why while HTTPs website can not perform SQL injections ?
This is SQL injection and did you pass the exam?

discussion.content: This question is on the exam.

choices.C: Disabling the use of HTTP and requiring the use of HTTPS
choices.D: Installing a network firewall in front of the application
choices.B: Requiring the application to use input validation

questions.question_text: The board of directors made the decision to adopt a cloud-first strategy. The current security infrastructure was designed for on-premises implementation. A critical application that is subject to the Federal Information Security Management Act (FISMA) of 2002 compliance has been identified as a candidate for a hybrid cloud deployment model. Which of the following should be conducted FIRST?

choices.D: Review the SLA for FISMA compliance.

comments.content: why would they "C. Review current security controls - Because this is for a hybrid cloud deployment model. (Onprem + Cloud)

discussion.content:
"The current security infrastructure was designed for on-premises implementation" so why would they "C. Review current security controls." If the current implementation is for on-prem and they are moving to cloud?

This would call for a new investigation, meaning B is the correct answer.
Review current security controls if it is aligned with the goals of FISMA before doing the risk assessment and other requirements?

comments.content: https://www.comparitech.com/net-admin/fisma-compliance-checklist/ Step #1: Maintain Information System Inventory. C seems closest answer.

questions.question_text: Joe, an analyst, has received notice that a vendor who is coming in for a presentation will require access to a server outside the network. Currently, users are only able to access remote sites through a VPN connection. Which of the following should Joe use to BEST accommodate the vendor?

choices.C: Turn off the firewall while the vendor is in the office, allowing access to the remote site.
choices.D: Write a firewall rule to allow the vendor to have access to the remote site.
choices.B: Set up a VPN account for the vendor, allowing access to the remote site.
choices.A: Allow incoming IPSec traffic into the vendor's IP address.

comments.content: The only way to get to the remote site is through VPN connection, at least that is a first steps in giving access to the remote site.
